data.title: Longtime curator of history, Dan Hobby assumes one more role
data.meta_description: By Judy Wilson | Associate Editor Pompano Beach – After years of being regarded as a person with an admirable knowledge of local history, Dan Hobby has officially become this city’s historian. Dan Hobby is the third person to be named Pompano Beach’s official city historian. [Staff] The former administrator of historical societies and sites
data.text:
By Judy Wilson | Associate Editor

Pompano Beach – After years of being regarded as a person with an admirable knowledge of local history, Dan Hobby has officially become this city’s historian.

The former administrator of historical societies and sites since 1979, Hobby was given the “largely honorary title” back in June after the death of Hazel Armbrister. It comes with no pay and no stated responsibilities. But it gets Hobby, who retired from paid positions in 2017, back on his game.

Before he became official, he was assisting city administrators with an historical conundrum: the status of the Rolle House on Northwest 3 Avenue, a 900-square foot home built in the 1940s by stage and TV actress Esther Rolle, best remembered for her role in Maude and “Good Times.” A graduate of Blanche Ely High School, she is buried at Westview Cemetery.

Now owned by others, the house has become a “cause celebre,” according to Hobby.

An ad hoc group wants to buy it as a tribute to the family. But it has been altered from its original design and is now a duplex. So that, Hobby said, is a problem. And then there is a continuing concern: Should the city take on the expense – maintenance, staffing, etc.?

“There is the problem of what to do with it,” Hobby said. “History is replete with saved buildings which now are in disrepair.”

Rolle never lived in the home that bears her surname, residing instead with a sister in a home near the Larkins Center which is no longer standing.

Hobby is this city’ third person to hold the title of official historian. The late Bud Garner, who died in 2016 and whose personal memories of Pompano Beach went back for most of his 89 years, held the post for many years. Armbrister, renowned in the black community for her efforts to preserve historic sites there, succeeded him and died last March.

Now it’s Hobby’s turn to advise city officials on the efficacy of historic issues and sites. “It appears to be a lifetime appointment,” he says wryly.

Readers of local history will recognize his name as an author. He has written seven books about the area including: “Pompano Beach: A History of Pioneers and Progress,” “Lighthouse Point: The First Fifty Years” and “Broward County: A Contemporary Portrait.”

A 1973 graduate of the University of Florida with a masters in history, he directed the Pompano Beach Historical Society for 14 years. It is an organization that remains dear to him. From 2000 to 2017 he oversaw operations at the Sample McDougald House including its historic move from Dixie Highway to the city’s Centennial Park. He remains on that executive board.

Prior to that he headed up the Fort Lauderdale Historical Society for 20 years and has served on numerous boards involved in historic preservations and places.

And beginning again in November, he will once again host the city’s historic tours, a two-hour trolley ride to 50 areas of interest.

Hobby suggests the city needs an aggressive agenda of identifying sites that might be suitable for historic designations. Among the most successful are the Ali Building, BaCA in the old Bailey Hotel and the two Kester Cottages at Founders Park, built by William Kester in the late ‘30s to kickstart tourism in this farming community.

At one time, on A1A, there were 120-150 of these small, affordable dwellings, built of Dade County Pine, lumber that withstands hurricanes.

History does “have an effect on our lives,” Hobby said.

For some, he said, it’s merely entertainment; for others, it supplies insight . . . but for everyone, it is a “moving target. Just like with this virus, we keep learning new things. Fifty years from now, we will be writing histories that see things differently. And we are always bound by our own perspectives.”

He adds, “I feel I can provide useful information for decision making. A reasonable role for a city historian.”
